testimony:
Welcome everybody.  Today we have two hearings that have been placed on the roll.  The hearing that we'll be commencing with concerns the applications of Mr Pieter Breytenbach and Mr de Wet Johan Strydom.
CHAIRPERSON EXPLAINS TRANSLATION EQUIPMENT

Before we start I'd like to introduce the Committee.  On my right is Doctor Tsotsi, he is an attorney and comes from Port Elizabeth, and member of the Amnesty Committee.  On my left is Mr Sibanyoni, he is also an attorney, he comes from Pretoria.  I am Selwyn Miller, I'm a Judge from the High Court from the Eastern Cape attached to the Transkei Division there.  	I'd request the legal representatives please to place themselves on record.
As it pleases you, Honourable Chairperson, Members of the Committee.  H J Prinsloo, I appear on behalf of the first applicant.

Thank you, Mr Prinsloo.
MR PRINSLOO
I am Louisa van der Walt, appearing on behalf of Mr de Wet Strydom.
Thank you, Mr Chairman, Gordon Taka.  I'm practising locally and representing the victims in the second hearing in the application of ...(indistinct) and others.
So you're not involved in this matter?
Mr Chairman, I'm Zuko Mapoma the Evidence Leader for the Committee.
Thank you.  When we met earlier this morning, Mr Prinsloo you indicated that the hearing will commence with the evidence of Mr Strydom.
It's over to you, Mr Prinsloo.
I call the second applicant, Mr Strydom, but before he gives his evidence there are certain aspects with regards to his application which if you give me leave, I would like to amend.
I see that he says that he was born in 1996.

It's a bit young.  The first reference is on page 36, it should be '64.  Then on page 43 it is again at the birth date but there the birth date is 19, it should be 29 March.  The year is correct there.  Then on page 49 there is a General's name which should not be there, it's on page 47 paragraph 16.  In the middle you'll find five Generals and then General Oelofse's name should be deleted.  The applicant will explain this to the Committee.  On the same page, paragraph 16, the sixth line from the bottom where it's written: General Oelofse should be General Etsebeth.  On page 53, paragraph 27, the fifth line in the paragraph it the same, General Oelofse should be replaced with General Etsebeth.  Thank you, that is  all.
Mr Prinsloo, do you have any objection?
Thank you, we'll then effect those amendments as stated by yourself, Ms van der Walt.

Thank you very much.
	Mr Strydom, you applied ...(intervention)
EXAMINATION BY MS VAN DER WALT

Thank you, Chairperson.
	Your amnesty application is contained in this volume from page 36 up to 70.  You apply for amnesty for certain offences for which you were charged and it was postponed sine die pending on the amnesty application.
And the charges for which you're applying for amnesty appears on page 38.
And it's also the same charges as we find them in the bundle from page 71 onwards.

Mr Strydom, you gave your full particulars in your amnesty application.  You were a member of the Conservative Party as well as the AWB, is
that correct?
When did you join the AWB?
And you were also a member of the South African Police, is that correct?
And later you left the police service.
Very well.  During your service in the police force, did you do any border service?
How long were you at the border for?
I was there several times, three months at a time.
And you also completed several courses in your career as a police officer, is that correct?

During 1992 - if I can refer you Chairperson to page 64 of the volume, it starts at the bottom - sorry, 45, the bottom of 45, I apologise.  	During 1992 you presented courses of the AWB and you attending them.
What was the purpose of these courses?
Chairperson, the purpose of these courses were to train people in the use of explosives.
Chairperson, the instructions we received was to present these courses so that the election would not happen and then also to create chaos all over the country.
And the AWB had several Generals who were involved in these courses and training, is that correct?
And the leader of the AWB, Eugene Terre'blanche, did he have any knowledge with regards to the training the AWB people underwent?
Yes, he knew about it all the time.  He knew about the courses and the training which took place.
You've mentioned several names in this paragraph,  In paragraph 9 on page 46 you mention several Generals there.  They had a specific name, what were their ranks as Generals?
They were the fighting Generals of the AWB, Chairperson.
Why were they called like that?
They were fighting Generals because in each district or area they gave the main instructions which would lead to war.
So the AWB prepared them for war?
And you also said they did not want the election to take place, why were they opposed to this election?
Chairperson, according to the AWB it would have been a majority election and it would have moved on towards a communist party and the AWB didn't approve of that.
What was Eugene Terre'blanche's viewpoint during all the meetings which you attended, what did he say with regards to the elections?
That an election should not take place, Chairperson and no negotiations would take place either with the ANC.
What did he say, did he say that there'd be negotiations in any manner or what was his point of view?
Chairperson, most of the meetings I attended he said that only through a barrel of a gun there would be negotiations with any communistic party, including the ANC.
And what did you think, what did you think of these meetings and what was told to you?
At that stage I believed firmly that it was indeed correct, Chairperson.
Did you also prepare yourself for the war?
Very well.  During 1992 on Jakob Morkel's farm in Khuruman you attended the camp of the AWB, is that correct?
And this camp, did it have any influence on you?
Yes, Chairperson, there I really saw that this country was heading towards a majority election and everything must be done to stop that, under the instructions of the AWB.
So did you become more active in the AWB?
In 1993 I really became active within the AWB.
If you say active, what exactly do you want to tell the Committee, what does that imply?
Chairperson, in those years I received instructions from my fighting General to start with the explosive gathering and also to start training the people in the use thereof.
You speak of the General, is this the General under whose command you functioned?
And were you in a specific division of the AWB?
We were a special force of the AWB with the aim to identify the insurgents of the AWB, people who infiltrated the AWB.
What exactly do you mean?  Were these people who infiltrated the AWB which you then had to identify?
That is correct, Chairperson, people from other parties, for example the ANC or the National Party, Chairperson.
Sorry, Mr Strydom, did that special force have a name?
We were known as the Special Forces.

Sorry, Ms van der Walt.
	Were you working at that time or were you involved fulltime with the activities of the movement, the AWB?
Chairperson, I did work at that stage, I was a traffic official.
Where were you a traffic official?
In 1993 I was a traffic official on Ottosdal, Chairperson.
And these Special Forces which fell under the command of General Fourie, who were these people?

Chairperson, there was a person who fell directly under the command of Fourie.  We knew him as Oscar, I didn't have another name for him.  There was also - we were several people from several districts.  There was Piet Prinsloo from Bloemfontein, Johan van Zyl from Khalahari district, Johan Welgemoed who is now deceased was in the Zululand district and myself for the diamond district, Chairperson.
This diamond region, which area did this entail?
It was mostly the Western Transvaal and also parts of the Free State, for example, Hoopstad and more.
Very well.  Why were there different people from different regions who fell under the command of General Fourie?
It was in order for us to present courses all over the country.  All the people were experts in explosives.
So you did not only act against anti-insurgence units but you gave training in explosives?
Did you have any members under your command?
Mr Piet Breytenbach and he is also applying for amnesty, and also Mr Piet Wessels.
So this happened in your region, the diamond region?
And both these people, were they both members of the AWB?
What was your rank when you were in command of these members as part of the Special  Forces?
I had the rank of Kommandant during that time.
And the other applicant, Mr Piet Breytenbach, what was his rank?
Originally he was a Field Cornet but by the time we started our activities he had the rank of Kommandant as well, Chairperson.
But he was under your command?
He had the rank of Field Cornet, Chairperson.

And you go further in paragraph 13, page 47, Chairperson.  You make mention of the fact that in November 1993 you were given instructions by the head Kommandant, Burger Terre'blanche to present training courses in explosives, is that correct?
Yes, I did present these courses, Chairperson.
And these courses, who were they presented to?
Chairperson, at that time my first course was for Mr Piet Wessels and Piet Breytenbach, Chairperson, as well as the head Kommandant Burger Terre'blanche.  He also attended these courses.
And these are the course you presented at Sannieshof?
Did you also give courses to other people in the AWB?
Yes, I did, Chairperson, it was the instruction of the Kommandant of the different regions and certain people were identified who then had to be trained.
And that was then in the use of explosives?
And during February 1994 there was a meeting at Ventersdorp, can you just tell the Committee were meetings often held at Ventersdorp?
Yes, there were lots of meetings held there.
Why was Ventersdorp the place where meetings were to be held?
Because the head office of the AWB was situated there, Chairperson and it was also centrally located to all the, as far as all the fighting Generals are concerned.
And Eugene Terre'blanche, was that also his office?
Yes, that was indeed the case, it was his office.
And during this meeting did you receive any instructions?
Yes, I did, Chairperson.  At this meeting I received instructions from my General, Nico Fourie, to start with this onslaught against the election which was to follow.
And this General Fourie, was he one of the Generals who died in the skirmish which took place in Mmabatho?
Can you remember the exact date when you received this instruction?
But it was before the Mmabatho incident?
And was it said to you that you must now start with the operations?  Where would this have been?
It would have taken place in my region, the diamond region.
And did they tell you which targets you had to identify?
Yes, the targets were white schools which became non-white schools, as well as any institutions which the National Party or the ANC Alliance was in favour or they were in favour of those parties.
And were instructions given with regards to certain people?
That is correct, Chairperson.  People in the ANC who were in favour of the ANC/PAC Alliance and more specifically their businesses or their property.
What was the purpose, why did you have to focus on these targets?

Chairperson, according to the information which we received and also the instruction, these were the people who in the community if we acted against them we would have been able to prevent the elections.
Are these then people who supported the ANC/SACP Alliance?
After the meeting in Ventersdorp you attended a further meeting - and that's on page 49, Chairperson, at a certain Mr Koos Hough, is that correct?
What type of meeting was this?

Chairperson, it was one of the big meetings during that time before the election.  The final planning would have been done there and the people in the diamond region would then go into action before the elections.
And what was discussed at that meeting?

They discussed - the BKA was present as well as the Volksfront members as well as the AWB, Chairperson.  The discussions were about the evening before the election and that specific evening bombs had to explode in the diamond region.
Now if you speak of the BKA, are you referring to the "Boere Krisis Aksie"?
And during that time there was also the Afrikaner Volksfront under General Constand  Viljoen?
And did these other parties also receive instructions?

My instructions were to create these explosions in Lichtenburg/Sanniehof/Ottersdal region, Chairperson.  And I received a direct instruction that day from General Etsebeth together with the leader, Eugene Terre'blanche to blow up a gas depot and also a railway line, Chairperson.
This gas depot, is that the gas depot at Lichtenburg?
Did you receive any further instructions?
The instructions which I received was that I also had to blow up the railway line.
And what about the instructions for General Fourie?
The instructions which I got earlier that year in Ventersdorp were still my instructions and it was that I had to train people in the use of explosives.
And after you received these instructions, did you do anything?

Chairperson, yes.  General Fourie's instructions I followed, I got explosives together, I trained people and the instructions which I received that day with regards to the Lichtenburg gas depot and railway line I did not execute them.
And then you started with certain explosions, is that correct?

Page 50, Chairperson.
	You and Mr Breytenbach, the other applicant then executed a certain operation in Bultfontein.
Chairperson, according to the information we received an ANC meeting would have taken place at Bultfontein.  Mr Breytenbach and myself then placed a landmine there, Chairperson.
Under whose instruction did you do that?
Under the instruction of the leader, Mr Eugene Terre'blanche, Chairperson.
Sorry, where exactly did you place the mine?
Where exactly did you place the mine, the landmine?  You said you put a landmine at Bultfontein but where precisely was it, in the street or where?
At the taxi rank in Bultfontein.  It was at the entrance of the taxi rank, Chairperson, in Bultfontein.
What did it look like, this area where the taxi rank was and where exactly did you place the mine?

Chairperson, as far as I remember the taxi rank was at the side of the town in Bultfontein.  The taxi rank had an entrance and an exit and the landmine was planted at the entrance or the exit, I can't remember, I'm not sure, but it was at the gate.
What was your purpose, why did you place it there?
The purpose was because an ANC meeting would have taken place there according to our information and it was in order to create chaos in order to prevent the elections from happening.
Very well.  So you've placed this explosive device at the entrance, did you want that a vehicle detonate this landmine?
That is correct, that is what we wanted to happen.  A vehicle would have created the explosion.
Chairperson, unfortunately a person with a bicycle went over the explosive device and unfortunately he died.  This is the person Kleinbooi Ramolla, is that correct?
Can you remember the date or the month?
It was in February, I think the 28th Chairperson.
Who was with you when you placed this device there?
Mr Piet Breytenbach, the other applicant, Chairperson.
It was only the two of you?
Yes, it was only the two of us.
The speaker's microphone is not on.
Sorry, Ms van der Walt, you're mike is not on.

You mention in paragraph 18 on page 15 that after the instruction of General Fourie you went and placed this bomb there, are these the instructions that you received in February of 1994 in Ventersdorp?  Is this the instruction to which you refer?
Did General Fourie specifically tell you to go to this particular taxi rank or did you have to find your own targets?
Chairperson, according to information that we had, we had to find our own targets, targets were not pointed out for us.
But the instruction was to create chaos specifically where ANC/SACP persons would be?
During May of 1994 - paragraph 19, Chairperson, on page 50 ...(intervention)

Sorry.
	Further explosions were caused by you.
Could you tell the Honourable Chairperson where and how this happened?
Chairperson, this was at Kazee's Cash Store, this was a shop.
Where, in which town was this?
This was in Sannieshof as well as Doringbult Primary School which was previously a white school and this was close to Delareyville as well as the Momoroti Primary School at Ottersdal.
Can we then start with Mr Kazee's Cash Store, why did you cause an explosion there?
Because he was a strong supporter of the ANC according to our information.
And at the Doringbult Primary School?
Doringbult Primary School was previously a white school, Chairperson, which was handed over.
And it became a non-white school.
The Momoroti Primary School was a school that was built by an AND supporter and was maintained by him.  This was a Mr Beukes in Ottosdal.
And these explosive devices according to your application did not detonate?
That is correct, Chairperson, they didn't explode.
So no damage was done to the properties there?
Sorry, Mr Strydom, why didn't they explode, were they found and defused or was it just faulty explosives?
Chairperson, most of them were faulty devices.
When you placed these explosive devices at the school, when would this be detonated, during the period that the children would be in school or in the evening or what was the position?
Chairperson, the bombs that we placed were for the purpose that it had to go off at night and the explosives were set for 3 o'clock at night.
And the one at the shop?
The same time, at three in the morning it would explode.
Not to cause any injury to people, it was more concerning the property of persons at that stage.
And then you mention on page 51 at paragraph 20 that about a week after you placed the explosive device you went to the SABC tower in Zweizereineke, is that correct?
Chairperson, at that stage the media was also seen as the enemy of the AWB as to their support of the government of the day at that stage and to the ANC Alliance.
And what did you want to do there?
We wanted to damage one of those broadcasting towers so it would not work in that area.
And did you do it then?
Chairperson, it did detonate but no damage was done to the tower.
You went back twice, is that correct?
And during April '94, was that - you cannot recall the specific dates, is that correct?
But this was before the election?
You placed another explosive device at Agriman at Ottosdal?
Why did you place the explosive device there?
The owner of the property was a BKA member and infiltrated the AWB and according to our information he would pass over intelligence to the Security Police who worked for the government.
And then you mention a Mr Smit who owned this business and you say he was an ANC orientated person, he was favourable towards the ANC?
Is this the one you speak of?
And who accompanied you when you placed this explosive device?
The devices did detonate and damage was done to the building as well as some other buildings in the surrounding area.
Nobody was killed or injured there, Chairperson.
When did you place this explosive device, during the evening or during the day?
This was at night and this one was also detonated at three in the morning.

Sorry, Ms van der Walt, just before you proceed.
	Mr Strydom, you've spoken now about placing explosive devices at those two schools and at Kazee's Cash Store, at the tower etc., now was Mr Breytenbach with you on each of those occasions?
On the 12th of April 1994 you once again placed explosive devices?
This was at the Sannieshof Liquor Store?
It was Mr Breytenbach and Mr Piet Wessels, one of the other persons whom I had on one of my courses.
Very well.  And you also went to a Doctor Breytenbach, a medical doctor?
You went to his consulting rooms and placed a bomb there?
Why did you place the explosive devices at these two places?

Chairperson, the information that we had at that stage was a person whom we knew as Johnny Portuguese, everybody in the are knew him as such, and he was favourable towards the ANC because he donated money to the ANC as well as Doctor Breytenbach who was a supporter of the ANC, Mr Chairperson.
And did these explosions take  place?
Yes, Chairperson, both explosions took place.
And was anybody killed or injured?
Once again nobody was killed or injured, Chairperson, this was also in the middle of the night, in the early morning.
Why at that stage did you take Mr Wessels with you and all the other times you only had Mr Breytenbach accompanying you?
Chairperson, because at that stage we stayed at Mr Wessels' farm and we manufactured explosives there and because he completed the course he went with us at that stage.
On page 52, paragraph 23 you mention that you stayed at Wessels' farm, this is at Groot Mariko, is that correct?
And you needed some more explosives, what did you do then?

Chairperson, I contacted General Etsebeth and told him that we needed some more explosives and a while after that I received a telephone call from an unknown person who gave me the delivery place of the explosives where we had to collect it.
That's the manner how you went about acquiring explosives?
That is correct, Chairperson, certain types of explosives which were not easily accessible.
How did you get your hands on these explosives, were they handed to you, what was the position?

Chairperson, the telephone call that I received from an anonymous person afterwards was to tell me that I had to collect the explosives on a bridge on the De La Rey Road.  He told us what time we had to be there and found the explosives there at the bridge but I did not see who delivered it there.
And where did you take the explosives to?
We went back to Mr Piet Wessels' farm, Chairperson.
I notice that in your application you say you went to the farm of Mr Piet Breytenbach's father and you buried the explosives there.
Yes, we went and buried it there but he had no knowledge of it.

Sorry, Ms van der Walt.
	What sort of explosives were these, Mr Strydom, were they military explosives or the sort of explosives they use on mines, dynamite, what was it?
It was more explosives that they used in the mines, Chairperson, Dyna Gel, Nitro Glycerine.  That is from fertilizer.
This was also received from the mines.
So Mr Breytenbach's father had no knowledge of what was stored on his farm or what you were busy with?
Did you go about this secretively?
That is correct, Chairperson, we did not want to involve many people.
At the AWB head office you collected detonators?
That is correct, Chairperson, it was a meeting that we had there where I contacted Mr Cliffie Barnard and he gave me some explosives at head  quarters.
Cliff Barnard, this is the accused who is responsible for the explosion in Johannesburg before the election?
And did he work at head office?
When you speak of head office where you collected these detonators, was this in the building or was it hidden somewhere?
Chairperson, it was in the building, it was a storage room in the office of head office in Ventersdorp.
The leader, Eugene Terre'blanche, would he be aware that these detonators would be stored there?
Chairperson, my personal opinion is that I believe that he knew.  It was a storage room where everyday cleaning agents were stored, brooms and such.
And you continue further on page 52, paragraph 25 you mention that you bought pistols, can you tell the Honourable Committee what happened there and why.

Chairperson, I did not buy the pistols myself, I had very little money at that stage.  Mr Piet Wessels who was with us the evening, when we bought the pistols at Hartebeesfontein or in that area where he bought three Z88 pistols with a cheque, a cheque of Mr Wessels.
From whom did he buy it?
He bought it from Mr Lukas Swart of the BKA at that stage.
And why did you buy these weapons?

Chairperson, we bought the weapons because it was cheap and at that stage it was difficult to acquire weapons and when we found the place to buy it we bought it so it could be used in the war when we go over to war.
Do you have any knowledge whether Eugene Terre'blanche at several meetings mentioned that you had to acquire weapons for the war?
Chairperson, at several meetings he said that we had to collect weapons as well as ammunition and if we couldn't buy it we had to steal it.

And the farm where you and Mr Breytenbach lived, were you also in possession you and Mr Breytenbach, you were also charged of the possession of a 357 Taurus and a 308 rifle and several rounds of ammunition, where did you get these weapons?

Chairperson, the revolver was Mr Piet Breytenbach's as well as the rifle.  I think one of the two he inherited and the other on he bought and it was being handed over to him.  The weapons were stored in a cupboard on Groot Mariko, Mr Wessels' farm.
And there were no licences for these firearms?
Not as far as I know, Mr Chairperson.
You continue, Mr Breytenbach, Mr Wessels and yourself were arrested before the elections, is that correct?
Why did you decide not to execute your instruction to blow up the gas depot in Lichtenburg?
Chairperson, the gas depot is located centrally in Lichtenburg, there are houses surrounding the place and it would have killed many people if we did execute our instruction there.
But you received the instruction from General Etsebeth, why did you not execute it?

Chairperson, I did receive the instruction from General Etsebeth with the approval of the leader, Mr Eugene Terre'blanche.  I did not execute the instruction because I did not go out to kill people, Chairperson.
What was General Fourie's opinion with regards to the killing of people?
At no stage did General Fourie give me any instruction to kill people or to injure any people.
Did you do any reconnaissance work in Lichtenburg at the gas depot?

You several times mentioned that you caused these explosions to stop the elections, what do you think would have happened, why did you think that the election would not go ahead if these explosions took place?

Chairperson, as soon as one causes chaos in any circumstances, it would not go as it was planned and the chief reason was to create chaos before the elections to keep the people away from the voting boxes so that they do not vote.
So you wanted to install fear in the public?
Did you personally gain in this?
No, Chairperson, at no stage.  Not even with bail did I receive any assistance.
And on whose behalf did you commit these actions?
It was on instruction for the AWB and for my people and my fatherland.
Did you believe that you would further the objectives of the AWB in this manner?
That is what I believed, Chairperson.
Did you have any grudge against anybody where you caused these explosions or at the taxi rank?
None, Chairperson, I did not even know these people.  (end of tape)
... after there was a change in the country with regard to the acts that you committed?

Chairperson, I'm very sorry for what I've done.  After the time since we've been charged and we appeared in the Supreme Court and I can now see that things can happen if negotiated.  And we were told that the AWB would not, if they would negotiate it would not help because they were negotiating with a communist party.
Are you still a member of the AWB?
I work in St Lucia, Chairperson.  I am a traffic officer there.
After you were arrested, did you participate in any actions or meetings of the AWB?
And you also in Exhibit B state the objectives of the AWB and reasons as to why these actions were political actions, is that correct?
And do you confirm the contents of Annexure B?
Is there anything else you would like to add?
Chairperson, only that I am sorry for what I have done, and for as long as I live I will not do these things again.

Thank you, Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS VAN DER WALT
Thank you.  Mr Prinsloo, do you have any questions to ask the witness?

Thank you, Mr Chairman.
	Mr Strydom, when you planted the landmine at the taxi rank did you foresee the possibility that somebody could have died?

And according to a statement which you will find on page 98 of the bundle, Chairperson.  It's a statement of a certain Mr Manual Amaro Pereiro, and he says amongst others and I'll read it, it's in English
"In my opinion the only reason ..."
The words aren't very clear.
"... them had to plant bomb at my business was because I let black people sleep in my hotel."
Was that the reason why you planted the bomb there?
No, Chairperson, it was not the reason.
And the bomb you planted was part of the liquor store, it was not at the hotel.
Yes, it was at the liquor store next to the hotel, it had nothing to do with the hotel.
The applicant, Mr Breytenbach whom I represent, according to my instructions he always acted under your command on behalf of the AWB?
That is correct, Chairperson.  Even though we had the same rank I was still the senior officer whilst we fought this war.

Thank you, Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR PRINSLOO
Mr Mapoma, do you have any questions to ask the witness?

Yes, Chairperson, just a few.
	Mr Strydom, as I understand it there reason why you planted these explosives to the various places which you have just mentioned is because you did not want the elections to go ahead.
That is correct, Chairperson, in order to create chaos.
And because the then National Party Government was collaborating with the ANC towards those elections?
And you had to attack the ANC oriented areas and supporters, is that so?
The properties of those people, that is correct, Chairperson.
And in all these attacks that you waged, you have never attacked any National Party Government oriented property, is that not the case?
There was the tower, the SABC.  I don't know, they would vehemently deny that it was Nationalist Party but it was at that stage one could say.
It was a government paid for property.
But you can put the question.  Carry on, I'm not stopping you.
Why were your attacks - why were your targets predominantly ANC and not that of the National Party Government?
Chairperson, as you yourself said, it was not only the ANC, if you look at Agriman, that was also a National Party member, Chairperson.  And it was not only meant for the ANC.
And let us go to the bomb that killed Mr Ramolla.  You say you had to place that bomb because there was going to be an ANC meeting in that area?
But surely the meetings was not going to be at the taxi rank?
Chairperson, that was the means of transport as far as we knew because most of the ANC members would arrive by means of public transport, people who would have gone to the town.
And am I correct when I say that that taxi rank was a taxi rank used by the black people?
Yes, by ANC supporters for that specific meeting, Chairperson.
That was a public day, the taxi rank was used by everybody, not necessarily people for the meeting.
That's correct, Chairperson but we felt whilst we investigated this, that the person who was not a member of the ANC would not go to town that specific day because he would have been scared.
Why?  Why would a person not go to town because there's an ANC meeting?

Chairperson, if we look at the previous marches the ANC held in towns and the damage which was caused, because of that we inferred that any person who was not a member or supporter of the ANC would not go to town.  We also know that most of the workers did not go to work on such days.
Is it not because you attacked that place because you wanted to kill black people?
And at the school which was owned by Mr Beukes, Mr Beukes was not a teacher of that school, not so?
No, he wasn't a teacher.  He lives right opposite the school.
And there was no way that he would be injured if that bomb detonated?
The potential people who would be injured are those black children who were students at that school.
I did not hear the question properly.
Had the bomb that you planted there detonated, the only potential victims there are the black scholars who were attending that school, is ...(intervention)
No, Chairperson, the bomb which they found there had a watch mechanism and it would have detonated at 3 o'clock in the morning, like all the others.
Was it a boarding school, did they kids sleeping in a hostel there that might have been a victim if it had gone off?
No, Chairperson, it was basically just a school, people only attended the school during the day.

On page 94 of the paginated bundle there is a statement there by Mr Beukes, the owner of that school and on the 5th paragraph there, Mr Beukes denies that he was in any way oriented to the ANC, what is your comment to that?

Chairperson, everybody in the Ottosdal vicinity as well as Sannieshof and Delareyville know Mr Beukes and also knows that he's an ANC supporter as regards to politics and also that he strongly supported the National Party/ANC Alliance.

Thank you, I have no further questions, Chairperson.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MR MAPOMA
Ms van der Walt, do you have any re-examination?

No re-examination by Ms van der Walt.
NO RE-EXAMINATION BY MS VAN DER WALT
Doctor Tsotsi, do you have any questions to ask the witness?

Just a few, Mr Chairperson.
	Mr Strydom, I didn't follow you correctly.  You said Mr Beukes was a supporter of the NP/ANC Alliance.
With the negotiations yes.  According to the AWB the National Party since the release of the State President, Mr Mandela the National Party was in an alliance with the ANC.
You are referring to them negotiating the future of the country together, not necessarily that they were in partnership in any form?
Usually there are some night watchmen at schools, at this particular school was there no night watchmen?
You say you didn't implement the mission at Lichtenburg because there were people living there, you didn't go out to kill people.  Which people were living there?

People from the prison live around there, as well as policemen and all members of the public.  It had nothing to do with race, it was a multi-racial area.  There were people from all sections of society living there.

But if you were not going out to kill people, you wouldn't put a bomb at an entrance of a taxi rank because at that one specifically there will be a person who will be killed if that bomb was detonated.

That is correct, Chairperson, we foresaw that people could get injured with the explosive device in Bultfontein but it was more about the meeting and hopefully we wanted it to cause damage to a vehicle.  I was of the opinion that a big vehicle would create the explosion and that would be damaged.  Unfortunately it was a person on a bicycle.
Didn't you stop the mission at Lichtenburg because you foresaw that also white people were likely to be killed but the one at Bultfontein taxi rank exclusively black people would be killed?
In other words you were not racist in your activities?
No, not at all.  Since I can remember I've been working with all races in South Africa and I also have good friends who are from other races.  I'm not a racist.
Thank you, no further questions, Mr Chairperson.
Mr Strydom, that landmine that was placed at the taxi rank, was it a homemade landmine or was it a military landmine, they type that the army uses?
I don't know much about explosives but how powerful was that mine, let's say compared to the average landmine that's used by the military in a war situation?
Chairperson, if I can put it on a scale of 1-10, according to a military landmine I would say it's about 2 and military one would be about 10.

So your whole experience in this period that you've related, where you were a member of the Special Force, did you stay a member of that Special Force, you didn't become a member of the, or was it part of the "Ystergarde" or any other separate force within the movement?
No, Chairperson, we were used to work with them in groups at several meetings but I was not a member of the "Wen Kommando" or the "Ystergarde".
"Orde van die Dood" and those sort of divisions?
And after the death of General Fourie in Mmbatho, who did you report to?

His second in command who was then called Oscar.  I received instructions from him, but there weren't any more instructions because it was so close to the elections, Chairperson.  The last meeting was the one at Mr Hough's house where I received instructions from General Etsebeth together with the leader, Eugene Terre'blanche.  It was with his approval.
Ms van der Walt, do you have any questions arising out of questions that have been put by members of the panel?

No questions, thank you.
NO QUESTIONS BY MS VAN DER WALT

No thank you, Mr Chairman.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR PRINSLOO

No questions, Mr Chairman.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR MAPOMA
Sorry, there's another one to come.
Mr Strydom, it may happen that I didn't understand you very well.  In connection ...(inaudible).

It may happen that I didn't understand  you well.  In connection with the planting of the bomb at Bultfontein taxi rank, I thought I heard you initially say it was an instruction from Eugene Terre'blanche but when we read your documents it refers to General Fourie.  Can you clarify me on that one?
He was present and his instructions had the approval of Mr Terre'blanche.
Who is higher in rank between Eugene Terre'blanche and General Fourie?
Chairperson, Eugene Terre'blanche was the leader of the AWB, therefore he would have had the highest rank but General Etsebeth was the General under his command and he was a fighting General.
You say the order was authorised by him but given by General Fourie?
Ms van der Walt, any questions arising out of that last question?

No questions.
NO QUESTIONS BY MS VAN DER WALT

No questions, Mr Chairperson.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR PRINSLOO

No question, Chairperson.
NO QUESTIONS BY MR MAPOMA
Thank you, Mr Strydom, that concludes your testimony.

That is the case of the applicant.
WITNESS EXCUSED
